attachments.title: The Fallacy Of Android-First
attachments.text: In late 2012, we decided to launch Emu on Android first. It went against the conventional wisdom at the time, but we saw a real advantage. 16 months later, we’re back on iOS: Emu for iPhone launched on April 2. Here’s why Android didn’t work out for us...and why you should think carefully before going Android-first.
attachments.fallback: TechCrunch Link: The Fallacy Of Android-First

text: There was an article that I saw flash past on TC this weekend about the cost of android first being 2-3x largely due to tooling.
Was it the same one?
yeah, this article said that too
Yep! Same one
(I'm not a fast reader)
Sorry, didn’t read the article but is tooling = devices or are there software costs too?
Well, there's sunk time into dealing with the development environment in general on top of the device compat time

Studio is a *great* idea, but even people who do android every day (Kat for example) can't possibly keep up with the changes that they make to the build system - which in many ways is worse than Eclipse was... but its been fashionable to hate eclipse since i was in my early 20s
So every time there's an update, you have to kind of hope that your project is still compatible with the same environment that you were using 30 seconds before the update
then we get into issues like proguard...
There’s a new plugin by Jake Wharton that keeps your sdk up to date: <https://plus.google.com/108284392618554783657/posts/G5DzahzsJsi>

attachments.text: Announcing the SDK Manager plugin for Gradle Android builds. Local SDK missing? API level not downloaded? Support library repository out-of-date? These…
attachments.fallback: Announcing the SDK Manager plugin for Gradle Android builds. Local SDK missing? API level not downloaded? Support library repository out-of-date? These…

text: All this is before you even deal with device compat
So that plugin is a good example of whats wrong with their approach to it
And the android SDK team's approach to the dev community in general
I can’t argue with you there
"Try to keep up, ok? We realize we're smart, and maybe you're not as smart as we are"
*mic drop*
Interesting to think Open Source software is supposed to be economically accessible for both users and creators.
Android isn’t open source
uh… what?
